2.31 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [4th November, 1964] to Question [4th November, 1964].

    "That, in view of the seriousness of the situation which will affect the lives and properties of the people of Singapore following the pursuance of the present policy of military expansion and war by the Alliance Government, and the measures taken by the Central Government to coerce youths of Singapore to undergo military training, this Assembly calls on the Singapore Government to urge the Central Government to stop conscripting such youths for military service.".-(Mr Kow Kee Seng).

    Which Amendment was, to leave out -

    "the pursuance of the present policy of military expansion and war by the Alliance Government, and the measures taken by the Central Government to coerce youths of Singapore to undergo military training, this Assembly calls on the Singapore Government to urge the Central Government to stop conscripting such youths for military service"

    and insert -

    "Indonesia's policy of aggression and subversion, this House calls upon the Central Government to take all measures to secure the safety of the lives

Column: 254

and property of our citizens, and for this purpose to give our youth proper military training to help defend the sovereignty of our nation". - (The Deputy Prime Minister - Dr Toh Chin Chye).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Mr Speaker: As agreed by the House, the debate on the motion and on the amendment will be proceeded with simultaneously. The Member for Jurong had the Floor just before the Assembly rose last night. Mr Chia Thye Poh.

2.33 p.m.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, we see that the present situation is serious enough. We also see that a lot of money earned by the sweat and blood of the people has been used to buy foreign arms,and to bring into this country foreign soldiers, rockets and other things to preserve Malaysia and to continue with the suppression of the people and their just struggle. Thus, under these circumstances, this territory will become an arena for Anglo-American imperialists and colonialists for their trial of strength. The purchasing of foreign armaments can only give wealth and benefit to foreign manufacturers of arms and can only bring misery and suffering to the people in this territory. Not only are the people faced with economic bankruptcy, they are also facing the calamity of disruption and breaking-up of their families.

    The North Bornean uprising is the struggle of the people to free themselves, but the British have been brought there to continue to suppress the people, thus expanding the war. After observing the situation in North Borneo, certain British military officers say that the war there will continue for quite a long time, perhaps eight or 10 years, maybe longer. It will be a protracted war. Even the British themselves are not sure of the duration of the war, and are not sure of the outcome of their armed suppression of the people there. So, resorting to arms and war cannot solve the problem at all. Not only that, it will bring

Column: 255

more suffering and hardships to the people, will cause a squandering of Government funds, and will incur more and more hatred from the people. Under these circumstances, there are only two courses open to the political Parties. One is to solve the question of Malaysia politically. In other words, return to the people their basic rights; to disband Malaysia and to allow the people to decide for themselves their destiny. The other course is to continue with dictatorial and adventurous action and to gamble with the lives of our youths and to make cannon fodder of them.

    Now, the Alliance Government have chosen the second course. They would not like to rectify the error they have made. At the same time, they think that they can bamboozle the people by covering up their present embarrassment. They have put up slogans such as "Defend the Country" and the rest of it in order to divert the people's attention. We have now seen the psychological warfare and many other campaigns waged by the Government. This psychological warfare has been conducted in many fields, such as patriotic conferences, confrontation exhibitions, forums and the rest of it. But no matter how and in whatever way the Government carry out this campaign, the purpose of it all is to distort the truth and confuse the people by catch phrases and slogans in order to extend the war to preserve their consolidated interests. True patriots have been branded as pro-Indonesia and traitors. At a recent exhibition put up in Singapore, even Inche Boestaman was branded as a traitor to this territory. Boestaman was arrested because of his past struggle against the British colonialists. His arrest only proves the pro-colonial inclination of the Party in power. But we can also understand the hue and cry made by the Government. They will put out more catch slogans and phrases. They will continue with their present line of action and repeat cant phrases in order to maintain their own position. The real anti-national traitors in the Party in power will continue to resort to old tactics and intrigues. We have sufficient facts to see through them.

Column: 256



    China has also been accused by Chiang Kai-shek as a Soviet stooge. Other countries have been branded by these Rightists as Communist stooges. No matter how the Party in power wage psychological warfare, the people are still clear in their hearts.

    In Borneo there are about 2,000 youths who have escaped into Brunei. Why should they do so? Because they do not want to be conscripted into the army to fight other people's cause. The Chief Minister of Sarawak also said that about 20,000 youths in Sarawak had disappeared. They did not want to join national service. This is a most regrettable matter to him. Even in Malaya and Singapore there are also thousands of youths who do not want to be enlisted and become cannon fodder. According to the Government of Singapore, there are about 50,000 youths in Singapore who are eligible for national service. But, in fact, the actual figure given by them is 70,000. Many Singapore youths do not want to enlist. The Deputy Prime Minister said yesterday that the number was 50,000. So it was 20,000 less than the official figure of 70,000. What is the actual position? We do not know. Only the Party in power know the actual facts. From this difference in the figures quoted, we can know that the Government are playing with figures. No matter how they do it, the youths of Singapore still do not want to enlist as and become soldiers and cannon fodder. If the Party in power describe this unwillingness on the part of Singapore's youths as being anti-national and traitorous, then I say that there are thousands more of these youths in Singapore, including some members of the P.A.P. in the lower stratum, who refuse to listen to the cries of the P.A.P. leadership to join the national service. They do not want to take part in any military training in spite of intimidation and propaganda. So if they call us anti-national, then there are some members who are not only anti-national but also anti their own Party. This shows that the P.A.P. itself is not even in a position to bluff its own members, to say nothing of the people at large.

Column: 257



    The refusal of the people to take part in national service is gathering momentum. Appreciating this difficult situation and losing confidence in Malaysia itself, the Prime Minister keeps on saying that we should have confidence in Malaysia. His repeated statements about having confidence in Malaysia show that he himself lacks confidence. That is why he wants to use words to restore the confidence of the people in Malaysia. In fact, he went to London to get help to solve his present embarrassment.

    The opportunistic P.A.P. leadership has no guts to go against the unreasonable policies of the Alliance Government. So it has no alternative but to follow the policies of the Alliance, much against its will. We know that the present situation of the P.A.P. leadership is rather tragic and regrettable. Who knows that one day the Prime Minister of Singapore may be degraded to the position of Chief Steward of Singapore? If the leadership still continues to play with politics, then one day it will find itself in a very difficult situation.

    Mr Speaker, no matter how much the P.A.P. smear us, our loyalty to the people at large will be appreciated by the people themselves. Our determination to go against Malaysia and conscription is unshakable. We believe that only the people themselves can solve their own problems. They cannot be solved by British soldiers. The people of Singapore have already made their contribution by way of opposing Malaysia. Our leaders have gone to gaol because of their opposition to Malaysia. Internationally there are countries which are against Malaysia.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): On a point of order. Under the amended Standing Orders, the Member is allowed a maximum of one hour to deliver his speech. Yesterday he had the Floor for at least 45 minutes. I think by now he has exceeded the time limit.

Column: 258



    Mr Speaker: Order. I have got a brief on my table which says that the Member for Jurong was on his feet yesterday for 21 minutes.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): If you say that Afro-Asian countries are for the struggle against Malaysia, then it shows that our stand against Malaysia is correct. If the ruling Party says that it is because we are against Malaysia that others also follow us, then it means that we are very strong to be able to influence others to accept our stand against Malaysia. In fact, there are some 50 countries in Afro-Asia which are against Malaysia. So the Party in power is less influential than we are. In spite of the tours of the Prime Minister to Africa and other countries, he has not been able to enlist support for Malaysia from the Afro-Asian nations. What we want to remind the Party in power is that we never expect any foreign power to replace our own power and strength against Malaysia. So long as Malaysia remains in existence and so long as military expansion is the policy of the Government, we shall continue to go against Malaysia and conscription. We shall not change our stand unless they change their policies. And the people will suffer as long as their policies are not changed. One day when the Prime Minister himself meets with difficulties, then he will realise and admit that our stand against Malaysia is correct and that our stand against conscription is proper and correct.

    Mr Speaker, that is all I wish to say.

2.52 p.m.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, in speaking on the motion and the amendment to the motion, I wish to deal with the problem in a way which may be of interest to the business community in Singapore, particularly to the Chinese business community.

    The original motion as proposed by the Barisan Sosialis is intended to weaken the resolve of our citizens to stand up to the undeclared war waged by Indonesia against us, which is called confrontation. There has been an unending series of incursions across the Sabah and Sarawak borders by Indonesian

Column: 259

armed forces. In recent months Indonesian commandos and paratroopers have landed on the Malaysian mainland itself. Here it is not a case of the Malaysian Government and we waging war against the Indonesians. Quite the reverse. Indonesian armed forces consider themselves entitled at will to invade our territory. In the face of this military threat, the Barisan Sosialis believe that the best solution is to disarm ourselves. No doubt the Barisan Sosialis will welcome the occupation of Singapore and other Malaysian territories by the Indonesian army. But I believe that the overwhelming majority of our citizens have not the slightest desire for the country to be occupied by the Indonesian army.

    Put it in these basic terms, it is obvious where the choice lies. But in the present political and economic situation in Singapore, there may be members of the business community, especially the Chinese business community, whose businesses have been hit by confrontation and who may try to get a quick and easy solution. They are asking themselves: is there a short-cut whereby we can make peace with Indonesia and resume our formerly prosperous business?

    Now, I have been privileged to be present at the two Ministerial discussions in Bangkok and at the summit conference in Tokyo. I can therefore speak with some authority derived from personal contact and negotiations with the Indonesian leaders. I am in a better position than most Members of this Assembly to assess their intentions and, on the basis of this assessment, to say what the prospects are of an early and easy settlement with Indonesia. I have to say that there is none whatsoever, and that we must be prepared to live with confrontation for a very long time. Of course, we can settle on Indonesian terms, which simply means that we will divest ourselves of the means to stand up to military pressure which they may apply on any occasion in the future. A condition of the demand that we disarm ourselves is the early and complete removal of the British military presence.

Column: 260



    Unless we are prepared to give a timetable for the withdrawal of British military forces from Malaysia, a timetable acceptable to the Indonesian political and army leaders, there can be no peaceful settlement of this conflict between us. That was the position as I found it at the first Bangkok meeting. That was also the position when the summit talks collapsed in Tokyo last June.

    So the question that the business community, especially the Chinese business community, must face is this: do they want an early solution which will bring about an inevitable occupation of our country by Indonesian troops? Or are they prepared to stand up and fight? If there is any other way whereby we can achieve a peaceful settlement without risking Indonesian military occupation, I can assure this Assembly that we will try our best to get it. But in the nature of things it is just not on the cards, and we are therefore faced with the prospect of a long struggle. And here it is important that the Chinese business community make their calculations correctly. They would be extremely foolish to fall for the bait of early resumption of business when that bait contains the seeds of their own destruction.

    The Chinese business community in Indonesia, some 15 or more years ago, made a fatal and tragic error and they are now paying very dearly for it. Historians who have studied the fortunes of the Indonesian Communist Party were amazed at the support which a substantial part of the Chinese business community in Java extended to the P.K.I. in its early formative stage in the post-war years when the P.K.I. was operating for the first time in its history as a legal political organisation. Why the Chinese business community acted in this manner is still a mystery. Perhaps they were resentful over some nagging petty regulations or restrictions which the national Government imposed on them and, therefore, they decided to lend support to some opposition Party. Perhaps they thought that by giving money to the P.K.I., they could have a measure of control over their policy.

Column: 261

Whatever the reasons were, the course of events took a turn completely different from what they themselves had expected or hoped for.

    When the Indonesian economy deteriorated with increasing rapidity, the influence of the moderate Indonesian leadership declined, as I shall explain later. In their place hot-heads and ultra-nationalists emerged. When this happened, naturally a scapegoat must be found for the economic morass into which the country had floundered. The scapegoat then was the Chinese population in general and Chinese businessmen in particular. In large parts of Java, Chinese shops were closed down and the Chinese population physically driven out at the point of the bayonet. In many other places, their property was confiscated. And even when they were allowed to do business, it was on very restrictive and often humiliating terms. These facts are well known to our Chinese business community especially those who have business ties with the Chinese in Indonesia. Needless to say, if we are to be completely defenceless, as the Barisan Sosialis want us to be, then the occupation of our country by Indonesian troops will automatically take place and our Chinese businessmen cannot expect a treatment better than that which their compatriots received in Indonesia.

    In the early days of the P.K.I., on several occasions they came close to political extinction, principally because of pursuing anti-national political activities. But on each occasion the Chinese businessmen financed and even supported them organisationally so as to enable them to make a quick re covery. Mr Speaker, if you think it incredible that Chinese businessmen in Indonesia could support a Communist movement in that country, let me remind you of a certain elderly Chinese gentleman in Singapore who was openly in cahoots with our Communist comrades here. When he found to his chagrin that this got him nowhere, he did a startling somersault and he is now hobnobbing with certain interesting people on the ultra Right.

Column: 262



    To return to the situation in Indonesia. Before the assumption of total power by President Soekarno in 1958, we saw a series of Indonesian Governments headed by people such as Dr Hatta, Mr Soetan Sjahrir, Dr Djuanda and others. These are the ablest and most rational leaders which Indonesia has produced, and they bent all their energies to reviving the economy of Indonesia in order to raise the livelihood of the masses and the peasantry, to make business run more efficiently, to increase production in the estates and in the tin mines, the oilfields, and indeed in all sectors of the economy. They resolutely opposed political adventures such as the West Irian campaign. They concentrated all their energies on economic reconstruction. Unfortunately for them, their efforts came to nought. The principal reason for this is that the Communist Party of Indonesia, through its affiliated trade unions and peasant or ganisations, were able to frustrate each and every attempt at economic improvement. Strikes paralysed the ports, factories, estates, oilfields and other economic enterprises as and when the Communist leaders called for them. So when the rational economic solution attempted by Hatta, Soetan Sjahrir and others failed, the only course of action open to the Indonesian leaders was to play the line of hysterical ultra nationalism. In parti cular the leaders had to create external enemies whose imagined threat to the Indonesian revolution provided a rallying point. In this way they forestalled the time when the Republic of Indonesia would disintegrate. First, there was the West Irian campaign. When this was wound up successfully - and we in Malaysia, Mr Speaker, Sir, helped them in this venture - then a fresh external enemy had to be discovered. Unfortunately for us, this time the enemy they chose is us. The present Indonesian Gov ernment cannot make honourable peace with Malaysia because then President Soekarno and other Indonesian leaders would have to explain to the people why they are so desperately poor, and he would have no external adventure to divert his people's attention from their present abject poverty. So these are the

Column: 263

basic revolutionary forces that are propelling the Indonesian leaders in the present situation. Even if President Soekarno were to die, or if he were to be deposed today, I do not believe that the new setup that will emerge will be one with which we can come to terms on an honourable basis.

    There are some businessmen who wonder whether or not Singapore would not have been better off if she had not joined Malaysia. Businessmen who so believe this are calculating on the basis that in an independent Singapore the British military forces will remain for an indefinite period so as to prevent any possible take-over of the Government by the pro-Communist open-front organisations in the first place, and the Malayan Communist Party soon after that. Now this assumption of theirs about an independent Singapore is completely false. In the present world situation, with the emergence into independence of nearly the whole area of Asia and Africa, it would not be possible for the British to maintain their military establishments in Singapore if the elected independent Government of Singapore asked them to leave. This has happened in Ceylon, where the British once maintained a naval base in Trincomalee. So the alternative scheme to Singapore's entry into Malaysia which flight have avoided Indonesian economic confrontation depended for its survival and economic prosperity on the completely false assumption that British military power can remain to prevent the Communist take-over. But they cannot remain. What will happen if the Communists take over the government in Singapore, whether by fair means or foul? There will be a conflict between a Singapore and a Malayan Government. Such a conflict may start, first, by an economic blockade of the island with consequences more disastrous than Indonesian economic confrontation. This conflict will eventually escalate into war between the two territories. And let us not delude ourselves into believing that that cannot happen here. It has happened in other countries. Think of Korea, Vietnam, Laos, and Cyprus. And it could, and in my calculation probably would, take place if Singapore had gone

Column: 264

it alone. So we had no alternative but to press ahead with Malaysia.

    The troubles that we are facing are not of our own making, but are clearly the result of the decision of the Indonesian Government to interfere in our domestic affairs with the object of absorbing us. In this situation, we have one of two choices. First, to surrender, if not immediately, then through a so-called negotiated peace which would leave us defenceless against military occupation any time President Soekarno decides to carry it out. The second choice is to stand up and fight. It is only traitors in this country like the antinational, pro-Communist, pro-Indonesia, bankrupt political forces in the Barisan Sosialis which favour surrender to Indonesia. The Barisan Sosialis leaders, of course, hope that if they were to assist Indonesia in successfully subverting the country, they would be rewarded with high office under Indonesian military occupation, positions which they were unable to win in democratic elections.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me stress the gravity of the issue we are debating. We are not here like little children playing marbles in the backyard, or building sand-castles on the beaches; nor are we debating stand-pipes, schools or community centres. The issue before us is one of survival, of life and death, of resisting enslavement by a larger country with reckless leaders and a big army. The levers and instruments here are not nice speeches or delicate diplomatic manoeuvres, nor even more unpleasantly petty political intrigues and conspiracies. The levers here are those of naked power, power which, as a great revolutionary puts it, comes out of the barrel of the gun. Whether we like it or not, we live in a revolutionary epoch and right in the heart of the seething revolutionary arena of South-East Asia. It may be a good thing for me to remind hon. Members of what that same great revolutionary said of revolutions. He said, "A revolution is not an invitation to a banquet. It is not essay writing, embroidery, poetry or other nice and elegant things. It is the effective and organised use of violence."

Column: 265



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Inche Yaacob bin Mohamed Al-Haj)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, the speeches made by comedians like Charlie Chaplin in films and T.V, do not surprise us at all. But if such speeches come from the mouth of politicians who are Members of this House and if they are designed to weaken the spirit and determination of the people, then they must be deprecated.

    We are shocked to see the motion moved by the Barisan Sosialis, because at a time when Malaysia is facing con frontation from the enemy followed by incursions and aggression from the air, sea and on land, the Members of the Barisan Sosialis who claim themselves to be genuine patriots and who are lauded by their foreign masters are prepared to move a motion of a nature which will bring disgrace and dishonour to our nation. If hon. Members of the Barisan Sosialis will read between the lines of their motion and feel that there is no truth in it, they can withdraw it. We do not indulge in lies as the Barisan Sosialis are fond of doing in this House.

    Mr Speaker: Order. No Member of this House can be called a liar. Will the Member please withdraw the statement that the Barisan Sosialis Members in this House tell lies?

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj(In Malay): Mr Speaker. I am prepared to abide by your ruling. But the Member for Paya Lebar accused me of being a liar. Maybe. Mr Speaker, you did not hear the translation. Therefore, I had to rebut his accusation.

    Mr Speaker: I did not hear it. But if my attention had been drawn to it, I would have certainly done something about it. Please continue, Inche Yaacob.

    Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I withdraw the statement I made just now. If we read carefully the motion in the names of the Member for Jurong and the Member for Paya Lebar, we can arrive at this conclusion, that it is a continuous link-up with those who call themselves "fighters of the national

Column: 266

Kalimantan Utara" led by Sheik Azahan and with the Voice from Jakarta. The object of this motion is purely to weaken the spirit of our people in order that our people, who have been known for their fighting qualities, can become cowards. Should this be the attitude of warriors of a nation which the Barisan Sosialis claim to be proud of?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a saying, "Do not beat a hornless bull because if you do so and he cannot attack you with his horns, he will find other means of attacking you." Similarly if our small Malaysia which loves peace is provoked by aggression, we are prepared to lay down our lives in its defence. How shall we show our integrity and honour in the face of this crisis at a time when our country is being attacked? We read from the newspapers that our youths are rallying to the call to defend their country. Thousands of them have come forward to register for military service and they have patriotically pledged to defend their country. They would rather be dead than just merely he alive. This is the pledge of true Malaysian patriots who love their fatherland. Even women have stated publicly in the newspapers that they want the Government to arm them for military service. They have called upon the youths of this country to defend our integrity and sovereignty. If any youth is not prepared to defend the country, then he should strip himself naked. The object of this motion is to weaken the determination of our youths. If our youths are not prepared to defend the country and they do not consider themselves to be warriors of the fatherland, then we cannot say that they belong either to the male or female sex.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is now clear that those who call themselves patriots and who are lauded by the so-called freedom fighters abroad are, in fact, the agents, henchmen and puppets of the new neocolonialism. Their argument is that Malaysia was forced upon the people of Singapore, Sabah and Sarawak. This is nothing new. The concept of Malaysia has been mooted long ago. We held a referendum to determine this issue. Malaysia was established before the

Column: 267

general elections were held in Singapore and Malaysia. In the general elections after Malaysia, the Parties against Malaysia were rejected by the people, if Malaysia was rejected by the people, then naturally the Parties who were against Malaysia would be in power today. But we know that the pro-Malaysia Parties received a clear mandate from the people. Was Malaysia then forced upon the people? I am surprised to see Members of the Barisan Sosialis with droopy eyes in the day.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we heard Opposition Members use the word "war", which, of course, has been brought about by the neo-colonialist power. Malaysia has never embarked upon any aggression. Even the Philippines which is claiming Sabah has not made any incursions into Malaysian soil. It is not Malaysia which is the aggressor. It is Malaysia that has been attacked by the Indonesians and a few traitors, as witnessed the landings in Labis and Malacca. If it is true that confrontation by our enemy is to protect or safeguard Malaysia, as alleged by the Member for Paya Lebar, I am very surprised why Indonesia is still reluctant to free Timor Island - an island which is not far from Indonesia - which is still being colonised by Portugal, and why the right of self-determination has not been implemented in West Irian. Why is this so if Indonesia is struggling for the right of self-determination of other countries? Why did Indonesia not say a word before Malaya achieved independence and before Singapore merged with Malaya at a time when Indonesia had friendly relations with Malaya? When Malaya realised its independence in 1957, surely Indonesia realised that British forces were still stationed in Malaya. Why was there no confrontation then? Why do they now claim that they want to liberate Malaysia from neo-colonialism?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to refer to something which took place 12 years ago. An Indonesian, Professor Mohamed Yamin, who was then the Minister for Education and Culture, was interviewed by an American journalist who asked him, "Is Indonesia claiming West

Column: 268

Irian from the point of view of history?" Professor Yamin answered, "No, we do not claim West Irian from the historical point of view. But we are claiming it from the point of view of Dutch colonialism. This includes Kalimantan Utara, Malaya and others." This was the basic intention of the Indonesian people. They wanted to absorb Malaya into Indonesia. This has been the basic struggle of the Indonesian leaders since 1945. They wanted to establish an independent Malaya within the framework of Indonesia Raya which was subsequently changed to Melayu Raya. This is nothing new to old freedom-fighters because this happened only some 11 or 12 years ago. It is only the newcomers who do not know about this struggle.

    The Member for Paya Lebar drew attention to the fact that his Secretary-General, Mr Lim Chin Siong, did give advice with a warning but that we did not heed it. His advice was that if Singapore were to join Malaya, the consequences would be grave. So the analysis of his Secretary-General has come true. The Barisan want the prediction of their Secretary-General to materialise, because in an interview with a journalist of Bintang Timor he said that it was better for Singapore to merge with Indonesia than Malaya.

    Mr Speaker, it is now clear who are the patriots of Malaysia. Unfortunately, the Member for Jalan Kayu is not with us now. Yesterday he said that conscription was not only against the wishes of the people, but it was forcing our youths here to fight against their brothers in Borneo or Kalimantan Utara.
